Literature Review: O-linked glycosylation plays a crucial role in the structure and function of viral envelope proteins, significantly impacting viral life cycles and host-pathogen interactions. This literature review aims to explore the current understanding of O-linked glycans in viral envelope proteins, their structural organization, and their diverse roles in viral biology and host immune responses.O-linked glycosylation is a post-translational modification initiated by the addition of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to serine or threonine residues on proteins. This process is catalyzed by a family of 20 different human polypeptide O-acetylgalactosaminyl transferases (GalNAc-Ts), leading to substantial glycan heterogeneity (Bennett et al., 2012). The resulting O-glycans can be found as solitary structures or clustered in mucin-like domains, contributing to the diverse functions of viral envelope glycoproteins.One of the primary roles of O-linked glycans in viral envelope proteins is their involvement in virus-host interactions, particularly for glycosaminoglycan-binding viruses. These negatively charged O-glycans facilitate viral attachment to host cells through interactions with cell surface glycosaminoglycans, such as heparan sulfate and chondroitin sulfate (Chen et al., 2018). This attachment mechanism is crucial for initiating the viral infection process.Interestingly, recent research has uncovered a novel mechanism based on controlled electrostatic repulsion that explains how viruses balance the need for efficient attachment to target cells with the requirement for effective egress of progeny viruses (Watanabe et al., 2020). This mechanism highlights the importance of O-glycan charge distribution in regulating viral-host interactions throughout the viral life cycle.In addition to their role in attachment, conserved solitary O-glycans have been found to contribute significantly to viral uptake in target cells by facilitating viral envelope fusion (Wang et al., 2016). This process is essential for the virus to enter host cells and initiate replication. The specific structural features of these O-glycans, such as their size and composition, can influence the efficiency of membrane fusion and, consequently, viral infectivity.The organization of O-glycans in mucin-like domains on viral envelope proteins has been shown to have important functional implications. These domains, characterized by dense clusters of O-glycans, can serve as molecular shields, protecting underlying protein epitopes from host immune recognition (Bagdonaite and Wandall, 2018). This glycan shielding effect can contribute to viral immune evasion strategies, allowing viruses to persist in the host despite the presence of neutralizing antibodies.However, the relationship between viral O-glycans and the host immune response is complex and multifaceted. While some O-glycans may block epitopes and hinder immune recognition, others can actually promote epitope recognition and enhance the host B cell immune response (Crispin et al., 2014). This dual role of O-glycans in modulating immune responses presents both challenges and opportunities for vaccine development.Recent studies have explored the potential of targeting specific O-glycan structures or their biosynthetic pathways as novel approaches for antiviral therapies and vaccine design (Watanabe et al., 2019). By understanding the precise roles of different O-glycan structures in viral biology, researchers aim to develop strategies that can either disrupt viral attachment and entry or enhance immune recognition of viral antigens.The role of O-glycans in viral spread within the host has also been a subject of recent investigation. Some viruses have been found to induce specific O-glycan modifications that may contribute to viremic spread, allowing the virus to disseminate more efficiently throughout the host organism (Walls et al., 2016). This finding highlights the potential for viruses to manipulate host glycosylation machinery to their advantage during infection.Furthermore, the study of O-linked glycosylation in viral envelope proteins has broader implications for understanding host-pathogen interactions and the evolution of viral strategies for survival and propagation. The diversity and adaptability of O-glycan structures suggest that viruses have evolved sophisticated mechanisms to exploit host glycosylation pathways for their benefit (Altman et al., 2019).In conclusion, O-linked glycans play diverse and critical roles in the structure and function of viral envelope proteins. From mediating initial host cell attachment to modulating immune responses and facilitating viral spread, these glycan structures are integral to viral biology. As our understanding of viral O-glycosylation continues to grow, new opportunities for therapeutic interventions and vaccine development are likely to emerge, potentially leading to more effective strategies for combating viral infections.
